title.narrative: Life-saving assistance to vulnerable IDPs and host communities in Sweida and Rif Damascus for backyard poultry raising for eggs production

description.narrative: The crisis in Syria will soon complete its fifth year, and it has severely limited the food production, marketing and importing. Latest assessments indicate that food is generally available in markets and shops across the country, although at a reduced quality and quantity and at a constantly growing price. In addition to the limited access to food, the purchasing power of families is progressively dropping due to low levels of income, lack of income –earning opportunities, inflation and steep depreciation of the Syrian pound. As a result, families can hardly meet their basic food needs, have an increasingly poor and unbalanced diet and are often forced to adopt unsustainable coping strategies leading to complete assets depletion. Findings from various assessments indicated that the quality of diet and micronutrient intake in Syria has markedly deteriorated with many households substantially reducing the consumption of meat, dairy products, eggs, vegetables and fruits. In order to avoid further deterioration of the quality of diet and micronutrient intake is therefore essential to strengthen food production capacities at household level. It is important to support homestead small livestock production given that traditionally poultry play a key role in the household's food security. This project will particularly focus on the provision of an initial set of inputs which can quickly improve household food availability and income. Back-yard farming is an activity often conducted by women that will benefit from this intervention as they will be prioritized in the selection. This support will be complemented by activities aiming at strengthening women technical skills, and will be implemented in cooperation with organizations addressing other constraints (in particular food nutrition and hygiene) of vulnerable households. Backyard food production activities will also benefit vulnerable groups with limited access to land, such as IDPs, landless rural population, urban and peri-urban populations. A close cooperation with other UN agencies, such as UNICEF, WFP and UNHCR will further improve the positive impact on beneficiaries creating synergies between the different assistance packages and making good use of the specialized expertise that each partner can provide. Each targeted household will get a poultry package of (15 chickens + 150 kg of poultry packages).
